The '''Inflation Reduction Act of 2022''' ('''IRA''') is a landmark<ref>{{cite news |last=Dennis |first=Brady |title=As Congress funds high-tech climate solutions, it also bets on a low-tech one: Nature|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/08/14/nature-climate-solutions-inflation-reduction-act/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=August 29, 2022 |date=August 14, 2022}}</ref> [[Law of the United States|United States federal law]] which aims to curb [[inflation]] by [[Deficit reduction in the United States|reducing the deficit]], lowering [[Prescription drug prices in the United States|prescription drug prices]], and investing into domestic energy production while promoting [[clean energy]]. It was passed by the [[117th United States Congress]] and signed into law by President [[Joe Biden]] on August 16, 2022. It is a [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|budget reconciliation]] bill sponsored by Senators [[Chuck Schumer]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[New York (state)|NY]]) and [[Joe Manchin]] (D-[[West Virginia|WV]]).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Everett |first=Burgess |date=July 27, 2022|title=Manchin and Schumer announce deal that includes energy, taxes |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/27/manchin-schumer-senate-deal-energy-taxes-00048325 |access-date=July 27, 2022 |website=Politico }}</ref> The bill was the result of negotiations on the proposed [[Build Back Better Act]], which was reduced and comprehensively reworked from its initial proposal after being opposed by Manchin.<ref>{{cite web |last=Zhou |first=Li |title=How Democrats plan to overhaul taxes, climate spending, and health care before the midterms |url=https://www.vox.com/23281547/build-back-better-joe-manchin-inflation-reduction-act |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=July 30, 2022 |date=July 28, 2022}}</ref> It was introduced as an amendment to the Build Back Better Act and the legislative text was substituted.

The law, as passed, will raise $738{{nbsp}}billion and authorize $391{{nbsp}}billion in spending on [[Energy in the United States|energy]] and [[climate change in the United States|climate change]], $238{{nbsp}}billion in deficit reduction, three years of [[Affordable Care Act]] subsidies, prescription drug reform to lower prices, and [[tax reform]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite web |title=CBO Scores IRA with $238 Billion of Deficit Reduction |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/cbo-scores-ira-238-billion-deficit-reduction |access-date=2022-09-21 |website=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget |language=en}}</ref> The law represents the largest investment into [[Climate change policy of the United States|addressing climate change]] in United States history.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nilsen |first1=Ella |title=Clean energy package would be biggest legislative climate investment in US history |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2022/07/28/politics/climate-deal-joe-manchin/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=31 July 2022 |date=28 July 2022}}</ref> It also includes a large expansion and modernization effort for the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS).<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last=Rappeport |first=Alan |date=2022-08-04 |title=The I.R.S. says new funding won't mean more audits for middle-income Americans. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/04/business/irs-audits-funding-congress.html |access-date=2022-08-10 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> According to several independent analyses, the law is projected to reduce 2030 U.S. [[greenhouse gas emissions by the United States|greenhouse gas emissions]] to 40% below 2005 levels.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Tankersley |first=Jim |date=2022-08-16 |title=Biden Signs Expansive Health, Climate and Tax Law |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/16/business/biden-climate-tax-inflation-reduction.html |access-date=2022-08-18 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The projected impact of the bill on inflation is disputed.

== Background ==
{{See also|Build Back Better Act|Build Back Better Plan}}

The Build Back Better Plan was a legislative framework proposed by United States President [[Joe Biden]] between 2020 and 2021. Generally viewed as ambitious in size and scope, it sought to make the largest nationwide public investments in social, infrastructural, and environmental programs since the 1930s [[Great Depression]]-fighting policies of [[the New Deal]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Build Back Better Framework |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/build-back-better/ |access-date=2021-11-14 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref>

The plan was divided into three parts: one of them, The [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021|American Rescue Plan]], a COVID-19 relief spending bill, was signed into law in March 2021.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web |last=Yarmuth |first=John A. |date=2021-03-11 |title=H.R.1319 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210226113259/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319 |archive-date=February 26, 2021 |access-date=2021-04-29 |website=Congress.gov}}</ref> The other two parts were reworked into different bills over the course of extensive negotiations within and among Congressional entities. The American Jobs Plan (AJP) was a proposal to address long-neglected infrastructure needs and reduce America's contributions to [[climate change]]'s destructive effects;<ref name=":02">{{Cite web |date=March 31, 2021 |title=FACT SHEET: The American Jobs Plan |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/31/fact-sheet-the-american-jobs-plan/ |access-date=March 31, 2021 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref> the American Families Plan (AFP) was a proposal  to fund a variety of [[social policy]] initiatives, some of which (e.g. paid [[family leave]]) had never before been enacted nationally in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-04-28 |title=Fact Sheet: The American Families Plan |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/28/fact-sheet-the-american-families-plan/ |access-date=2021-04-29 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref>

The Build Back Better Act was a [[Bill (law)|bill]] introduced in the [[117th United States Congress|117th Congress]] to fulfill aspects of the [[Build Back Better Plan]]. It was spun off from the American Jobs Plan, alongside the [[Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act]], as a $3.5{{nbsp}}trillion [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|reconciliation]] package that included provisions related to [[Climate change in the United States|climate change]] and [[social policy]]. Following negotiations, the price was lowered to approximately $2.2{{nbsp}}trillion. The bill was passed 220–213 by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] on November 19, 2021.

In December 2021, amidst of negotiations and [[Parliamentarian of the United States Senate|parliamentary]] procedures, Senator [[Joe Manchin]] publicly pulled his support from the bill for its cost and for envisioning a too aggressive transition to clean energy,<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Seipel |first1=Arnie |last2=Hernandez |first2=Joe |date=2021-12-19 |title=Joe Manchin says he won't support President Biden's Build Back Better plan |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2021/12/19/1065636709/joe-manchin-says-he-cannot-support-bidens-build-back-better-plan |access-date=2022-08-31}}</ref> then subsequently retracted support for his own compromise legislation. This effectively killed the bill as it needed 50 senators to pass via reconciliation, and all 50 Republican senators opposed it. 

In the summer of 2022, Manchin and [[Senate majority leader|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Chuck Schumer]] engaged in negotiations over a revised reconciliation bill with about $1 trillion of revenue from [[tax reform]], $500 billion in climate and health care spending, and $500 billion in deficit reduction.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Everett |first=Burgess |title=Manchin’s offer to Dems: Take a health care deal or try again later |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/14/manchin-rejects-climate-tax-elements-of-party-line-dem-bill-00046018 |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref> However, Manchin announced abruptly on July 14, 2022 that he wouldn't support new climate spending or tax reform due to his fear that the bill would worsen inflation.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Cochrane |first=Emily |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |date=2022-07-15 |title=Manchin Pulls Plug on Climate and Tax Talks, Shrinking Domestic Plan |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/14/us/politics/manchin-climate-taxes.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> He later stated that he would be open to revisiting those elements a few months later, provided that inflation slowed meaningfully.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Weissmann |first=Jordan |date=2022-07-15 |title=Joe Manchin Just Knifed What Was Left of Biden’s Agenda |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/07/joe-manchin-climate-spending-democrats.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=Slate Magazine |language=en}}</ref> Biden nonetheless conceded defeat on a climate bill, urging Congress to pass whatever Manchin would agree to (a slim, $280 billion health care bill that would acquire its revenue from allowing Medicare to negotiate prices and spend $40 billion on Affordable Care Act subsidies).<ref>{{Cite news |last=Tankersley |first=Jim |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |last3=Davenport |first3=Coral |date=2022-07-15 |title=Biden Concedes Defeat on Climate Bill as Manchin and Inflation Upend Agenda |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/15/climate/biden-inflation-climate-manchin.html |access-date=2022-12-31 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Everett |first=Burgess |title=Manchin’s offer to Dems: Take a health care deal or try again later |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/14/manchin-rejects-climate-tax-elements-of-party-line-dem-bill-00046018 |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref>

Unbeknownst to nearly everyone in Washington, Manchin and Schumer reengaged in secret negotiations on July 18, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lizza |first=Ryan |last2=Daniels |first2=Eugene |title=POLITICO Playbook: How it really happened: The Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2022/08/08/how-it-really-happened-the-inflation-reduction-act-00050279 |access-date=2022-12-31 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref> On July 27, the two men released a statement announcing the $738 billion Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, which included climate spending and tax reform.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Kevin Liptak, Manu Raju, Ella Nilsen and Alex Rogers |date=July 28, 2022 |title=How secret negotiations revived Joe Biden's agenda and shocked Washington |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/28/politics/manchin-schumer-biden-deal/index.html |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=CNN}}</ref>

The sudden deal was widely regarded as a 'shocker' as Democrats had voiced that there was little hope for a revival of their climate and tax priorities in addition to Manchin himself being rather pessimistic on the prospect of an expanded bill in public.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Manchin's latest shocker: A $700B deal |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/27/manchin-schumer-senate-deal-energy-taxes-00048325 |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref>

As the revised bill made its way through the chambers of Congress, the new reality of Biden unexpectedly having a clear path to enacting substantial portions of his domestic agenda into law led to a wide reevaluation of the success of the [[Presidency of Joe Biden|Biden presidency]] thus far and was expected to give the President and his party a boost in the [[2022 United States elections|2022 midterm elections]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Biden suddenly is piling up wins. Can Dems make it stick? |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/09/joe-biden-legislative-wins-00050461 |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Montanaro |first=Domenico |date=2022-08-12 |title=Biden's recent wins could give Democrats a boost heading into the midterms |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/08/12/1116745451/democrats-biden-midterms |access-date=2022-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Chait |first=Jonathan |date=2022-08-12 |title=Joe Biden's Best Week Ever |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2022/08/joe-biden-presidency-best-week-ever.html |access-date=2022-08-13 |website=Intelligencer |language=en-us}}</ref>

==Legislative history==
[[File:P20220816CS-0389 (52386878143).jpg|thumb|President [[Joe Biden]] signing the bill into law in the [[State Dining Room]] of the White House on August 16, 2022]]
The Build Back Better Act, which passed the House on September 27, 2021, was used by the Senate as the legislative vehicle for this legislation. On August 6, 2022 [[Senate majority leader|Senate Majority Leader]] Chuck Schumer proposed an amendment which would replace the text of the previously passed bill with the text of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022. This substitute amendment was later adopted.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Yarmuth |first=John A. |date=2022-08-08 |title=Actions - H.R.5376 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=http://www.congress.gov/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=www.congress.gov}}</ref>

On August 7, 2022, following the [[vote-a-rama]], an unlimited marathon voting session on amendments, that lasted nearly 16 hours, the Senate passed the bill (as amended) on a 51–50 vote, with all Democrats voting in favor, all Republicans opposed, and Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] [[List of tie-breaking votes cast by the vice president of the United States|breaking the tie]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Senate passes Democrats' sweeping climate, health and tax bill, delivering win for Biden |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/inflation-reduction-act-senate-pass-climate-healthcare-tax-bill/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=www.cbsnews.com |language=en-US}}</ref> On August 12, 2022, the bill was passed by the House on a 220–207 vote, with all Democrats voting in favor and all Republicans voting against it.<ref>{{Cite news |title=House passes Inflation Reduction Act, sending climate and health bill to Biden |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/08/12/inflation-reduction-act-house-vote/ |access-date=2022-08-12 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> On August 16, 2022, the bill was signed into law by President Joe Biden.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Maegan Vazquez |title=Biden signs Inflation Reduction Act into law |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/16/politics/biden-inflation-reduction-act-signing/index.html |access-date=2022-08-16 |website=CNN|date=August 16, 2022 }}</ref>

==Provisions==
Over a period of 10 years, the law is estimated to raise revenue from:<ref name="dem_sum">{{cite web |date=August 11, 2022 |title=Summary: The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/inflation_reduction_act_one_page_summary.pdf |access-date=August 12, 2022 |publisher=Senate Democratic Leadership |postscript=.Estimates from the [[United States Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation]] or [[Congressional Budget Office]], depending on the number.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |author=Manu Raju and Ali Zaslav |title=Sinema says she will 'move forward' on economic bill, putting Biden's agenda on the cusp of Senate approval |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/04/politics/chuck-schumer-economic-bill-saturday/index.html |access-date=2022-08-05 |website=CNN|date=August 4, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Kimball |first=Spencer |title=Passage of Inflation Reduction Act gives Medicare historic new powers over drug prices |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/12/drug-prices-passage-of-inflation-reduction-act-gives-medicare-historic-new-powers.html |access-date=2022-08-16 |website=CNBC |language=en}}</ref>
* Prescription drug price reform to lower prices, including [[prescription drug prices in the United States#Solutions|Medicare negotiation of drug prices]] for certain drugs (starting at 10 by 2026, more than 20 by 2029) and rebates from drug makers who price gouge – $281{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":7" /><ref name="Sachs 2022 ">{{cite journal | title=Understanding The Democrats' Drug Pricing Package |last=Sachs|first=Rachel |journal=Health Affairs Forefront | date=10 August 2022 |doi=10.1377/forefront |s2cid=245786874 | url=https://www.healthaffairs.org/do/10.1377/forefront.20220810.661571/full/ |access-date=5 October 2022 }}</ref><ref name="Cutler p=e223630">{{cite journal | last=Cutler | first=David M. | title=Medicare Enters the Pharmaceutical Purchasing Business | journal=JAMA Health Forum | publisher=American Medical Association (AMA) | volume=3 | issue=9 | date=2022-09-01 | issn=2689-0186 | doi=10.1001/jamahealthforum.2022.3630 | page=e223630| pmid=36218929 | s2cid=252035393 }}</ref><ref name="Investopedia 2022">{{cite web | last=Murphy | first=Rachel | title=How Prescription Drug Negotiations Will Impact Medicare Beneficiaries | website=Investopedia | date=2022-08-30 | url=https://www.investopedia.com/perscription-drug-negotiations-medicare-beneficiaries-6503437 | access-date=2022-10-05}}</ref>
* Imposing a selective 15% corporate minimum tax rate for companies with higher than $1{{nbsp}}billion of annual financial statement income – $222{{nbsp}}billion
* Increased tax enforcement – $181{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=CFP® |first=Kate Dore |title=With 87,000 new agents, here's who the IRS may target for audits |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/09/with-87000-new-agents-heres-who-the-irs-may-target-for-audits.html |access-date=2022-08-10 |website=CNBC |language=en}}</ref>
* Imposing a 1% excise tax on [[stock buybacks]] – $74{{nbsp}}billion
* 2-year extension of the limitation on excess business losses - $53 billion<ref name=":7" />

In the same time period, it would spend this revenue on:<ref name="dem_sum" /><ref>{{Cite news |last=Shivaram |first=Deepa |date=2022-08-12 |title=Democrats passed a major climate, health and tax bill. Here's what's in it |language=en |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2022/08/07/1116190180/democrats-are-set-to-pass-a-major-climate-health-and-tax-bill-heres-whats-in-it |access-date=2022-08-12}}</ref>
* Addressing domestic [[energy security]] and [[climate change]], including funding for drought resiliency in western states – $391{{nbsp}}billion
* [[Deficit reduction in the United States|Deficit reduction]] – $238 billion<ref name=":7" />
* Continuing for three more years the expansion of [[Affordable Care Act]] subsidies originally expanded under the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021]] – $64{{nbsp}}billion
* Increased funding for the IRS for modernization and increased tax enforcement – $80{{nbsp}}billion<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news |title=Democrats' $80 billion wager: A bigger IRS will be a better IRS |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2022/08/06/inflation-reduction-act-irs/ |access-date=2022-08-10 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

$270 billion of the law's climate action investments are embedded in the federal tax code.<ref name="Bravender 2022">{{cite web | title=Greenwire: Podesta, IRS get to work on climate law's tax incentives | website=Politico Pro|last=Bravender|first=Robyn | date=5 October 2022 | url=https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/eenews/2022/10/05/podesta-irs-get-to-work-on-climate-laws-tax-incentives-00060477 | access-date=8 October 2022}}</ref> As part of the overall $158 billion investment into [[clean energy]], the law extended the solar investment tax credit for 10 years<ref>{{cite web|last=Stevens|first=Pippa|date=July 28, 2022|title=Solar stocks jump as Schumer, Manchin announce climate spending deal |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/07/28/solar-stocks-jump-as-schumer-manchin-announce-climate-spending-deal.html |website=CNBC |access-date=August 7, 2022}}</ref> and invests $30 billion in [[nuclear power]]. It also invests $13 billion in electric vehicle incentives, $14 billion in home energy efficiency upgrades, $22 billion in home energy supply improvements, and $37 billion in advanced manufacturing.<ref name="Hank Green infographic">{{Cite AV media|people=Green, Hank|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qw5zzrOpo2s&t=650s|date=August 12, 2022|access-date=October 6, 2022|publisher=Vlogbrothers|type=YouTube video|location=Missoula, Montana|title=The Biggest Climate Bill of Your Life - But What does it DO?|time=10 minutes 50 seconds}}</ref><ref name="dem_sum"/> $20 billion goes to investments in [[climate-smart agriculture]], more than $5 billion goes to revising remediation programs for those affected by discriminatory [[USDA]] lending practices, $5 billion goes to forest protection and [[urban heat island]] reductions, and nearly $3 billion goes to coastal habitat protection.<ref name="DOE/OP-0018">{{cite report|title=The Inflation Reduction Act Drives Significant Emissions Reductions and Positions America to Reach Our Climate Goals|url=https://www.energy.gov/sites/default/files/2022-08/8.18%20InflationReductionAct_Factsheet_Final.pdf|publisher=United States Department of Energy Office of Policy|date=August 2022}}</ref><ref name="Philpott 2022">{{cite magazine | last=Philpott | first=Tom | title=How the Inflation Reduction Act Affects Food and Agriculture | magazine=WIRED | date=20 August 2022 | url=https://www.wired.com/story/how-the-inflation-reduction-act-affects-food-and-agriculture/ | access-date=20 October 2022}}</ref>

The law contains provisions that cap insulin costs at $35/month and will cap out-of-pocket drug costs at $2,000 for people on [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], among other provisions.<ref name="dem_sum" /><ref name="Sachs 2022 "/><ref name="Cutler p=e223630"/><ref name="Investopedia 2022"/>

Several provisions in the initial deal between Schumer and Manchin were changed after negotiations with Senator Sinema: a provision narrowing the [[Carried interest in the United States|carried interest]] loophole was dropped, a 1% excise tax on stock buybacks was added, manufacturing exceptions were added to the corporate minimum tax, and funding for drought relief for western states was added.<ref name=":2">{{cite web |last=Tully-Mcmanus |first=Katherine |date=2022-08-05 |title=Sinema's tax tweaks |url=https://politi.co/3zZv8b9 |access-date=2022-08-05 |website=Politico}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Cochrane |first=Emily |date=2022-08-05 |title=Sinema Agrees to Climate and Tax Deal, Clearing the Way for Votes |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/04/us/politics/sinema-inflation-reduction-act.html |access-date=2022-08-05 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Bolton |first=Alexander |date=2022-08-05 |title=Sinema announces deal with Schumer on taxes and climate |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/3588988-sinema-announces-deal-with-schumer-on-taxes-and-climate/ |access-date=2022-08-05 |website=The Hill}}</ref>

==Impact==

=== Economic ===
The nonpartisan [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) estimated that the bill would have no statistically significant effect on inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Inflation Reduction Act: Comparing CBO and PWBM Estimates |url=https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/issues/2022/8/5/inflation-reduction-act-comparing-cbo-and-pwbm-estimates |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=Penn Wharton Budget Model |language=en-US}}</ref> The [[Penn Wharton]] Budget Model also estimated that the bill would have no statistically significant effect on inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Senate-Passed Inflation Reduction Act: Estimates of Budgetary and Macroeconomic Effects |url=https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/issues/2022/8/12/senate-passed-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2022-08-15 |website=Penn Wharton Budget Model |language=en-US}}</ref>

The nonpartisan [[Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget]] analyzed the bill and concluded that the "deficit reduction, along with other elements of the bill, is likely to reduce inflationary pressures and thus reduce the risk of a possible recession."<ref>{{cite web |title=What's In the Inflation Reduction Act? |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/whats-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=July 30, 2022 |publisher=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget}}</ref> It further estimates that the bill would reduce the [[National debt of the United States|federal deficit]] by $1.9{{nbsp}}trillion over a 20-year period. This figure includes the resulting savings on interest payments.<ref>{{cite web |date=August 3, 2022 |title=IRA Saves Almost $2 Trillion Over Two Decades |url=https://www.crfb.org/blogs/ira-saves-almost-2-trillion-over-two-decades |access-date=2022-08-04 |publisher=Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget}}</ref>

The [[Tax Foundation]], a fiscally conservative think tank, stated that the bill "may actually worsen inflation by constraining the productive capacity of the economy." It estimated the bill would result in a loss of 29,000 [[full-time equivalent]] jobs and a 0.2% reduction in GDP, while resulting in $324{{nbsp}}billion of additional revenues, which would go towards deficit reduction.<ref>{{cite web |date=August 2, 2022 |title=Inflation Reduction Act: Details & Analysis |url=https://taxfoundation.org/inflation-reduction-act/ |access-date=August 4, 2022 |publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]}}</ref>

Modeling by the Energy Innovation group, a nonpartisan energy and climate think tank, estimated that this bill would lead to the creation of 1.4 million to 1.5 million additional jobs and increase the GDP 0.84–0.88% by 2030.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Climate change bill would cut U.S. air pollution deaths by up to 3,900 per year, study finds |url=https://news.yahoo.com/climate-change-bill-would-cut-us-air-pollution-deaths-by-up-to-3900-per-year-study-finds-191755579.html |access-date=2022-08-31 |website=news.yahoo.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

=== Energy and climate change ===
The Inflation Reduction Act is the largest piece of federal legislation ever to address [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Princeton energy and climate experts weigh in on the impact of the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2022/08/25/princeton-energy-and-climate-experts-weigh-impact-inflation-reduction-act |publisher=Princeton University |access-date=27 August 2022}}</ref> According to the CBO, it will invest $391 billion in provisions relating to energy security and climate change.<ref name=":7" /> This includes $270 billion in tax incentives,<ref name="Bravender 2022"/> and $27 billion for a [[green bank]] created by amending the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]].<ref name="Morgan Lewis 2022">{{cite web | title=Inflation Reduction Act Creates $27B 'Green Bank' Fund for Clean Energy Projects, but False Claims Risks Exist | last1=Avery|first1=W. Barron A.|last2=McCarthy|first2=Ryan A.|last3=Lorenzo|first3=Sarah-Jane|website=Morgan Lewis | date=August 16, 2022 | url=https://www.morganlewis.com/pubs/2022/08/inflation-reduction-act-creates-27b-green-bank-fund-for-clean-energy-projects-but-false-claims-risks-exist | access-date=October 22, 2022}}</ref><ref name="Burr & Forman LLP 2022">{{cite web | title=Three Ways the Inflation Reduction Act Advances Green Banking |last1=Penny|first1=William|last2=Snow|first2=Ed| website=Burr & Forman LLP | date=August 19, 2022 | url=https://www.burr.com/newsroom/articles/three-ways-the-inflation-reduction-act-advances-green-banking | access-date=October 22, 2022}}</ref><ref name="Cherny 2022">{{cite web | last=Cherny | first=Andrei | title=Commentary: This little-discussed provision in the Inflation Reduction Act just established the world's largest green lending program | website=Fortune | date=August 22, 2022 | url=https://fortune.com/2022/08/22/climate-inflation-reduction-act-national-green-bank-environment-biden-andrei-cherny/ | access-date=October 22, 2022}}</ref> In contrast, a report by [[Credit Suisse]] projects that the total climate spending in the bill would be significantly higher, at $800 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ultimate Public Climate Spending Spurred by Inflation Reduction Act Could be Over $800 Billion: Credit Suisse {{!}} American Public Power Association |url=https://www.publicpower.org/periodical/article/ultimate-public-climate-spending-spurred-inflation-reduction-act-could-be-over-800-billion-credit |access-date=2022-12-02 |website=www.publicpower.org}}</ref> The summary provided by Senate Democrats identifies primary goals as driving down consumer energy costs, increasing [[energy security]], and reducing [[greenhouse gas emissions]].

The largest allocation areas are: $128 billion for [[renewable energy]] and [[grid energy storage]], $30 billion for [[nuclear power]], $13 billion for [[electric vehicle]] incentives, $14 billion for home energy efficiency upgrades, $22 billion for home energy supply improvements, and $37 billion for advanced manufacturing.<ref name="Hank Green infographic"/> An assortment of additional measures includes $32 billion for investments in rural economies, racial justice in farming, forestlands and coastal habitats, $3 billion in tax incentives for installing [[carbon capture and storage]] at existing power plants, $3 billion to electrify the [[USPS]] fleet, $3 billion to reconnect neighborhoods harmed by infrastructure potentially via [[freeway removal]], investments in [[sustainable aviation fuel]], grants for [[high voltage]] [[electric power transmission]] and decarbonization of [[port]] equipment, [[garbage truck]]s, [[school bus]]es and [[local government]] fleets, purchases of [[rural electric cooperative]] debt alongside other assistance to cooperatives, and requirements that the government reduce [[embedded emissions]] in its procurement process.<ref name="Lechleitner 2022">{{cite web | last=Lechleitner | first=Liz | title=Electric and agricultural co-op leaders respond to passage of Inflation Reduction Act | website=NCBA CLUSA | date=August 23, 2022 | url=https://ncbaclusa.coop/blog/electric-and-agricultural-co-op-leaders-respond-to-passage-of-inflation-reduction-act/ | access-date=November 24, 2022}}</ref><ref name="DOE/OP-0018"/><ref name="Hank Green infographic"/><ref name="Philpott 2022"/><ref name="Stabenow one-pager"/>

The bill aims to decrease residential energy costs by focusing on improvements to home [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]]. Measures include $9 billion in home energy rebate programs that focus on improving access to energy efficient technologies, and 10 years of consumer [[tax credit]]s for the use of [[heat pump]]s, [[Rooftop solar power|rooftop solar]], and high-efficiency electric [[Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning#Energy efficiency|heating, ventilation, air conditioning]] and [[water heating]]. The bill extends the $7,500 tax credit for the purchase of new [[electric vehicle]]s while also providing a $4,000 tax credit toward the purchase of used electric vehicles, in an effort to increase low- and middle-income access to this technology.<ref name=":04">{{Cite web |last=Democrats |first=Senate |date=July 27, 2022 |title=Summary of the Energy Security and Climate Change Investments in the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/summary_of_the_energy_security_and_climate_change_investments_in_the_inflation_reduction_act_of_2022.pdf |url-status=live |access-date=August 22, 2022 |website=Senate Democrats}}</ref> This is projected to lead to an average of $500 in savings on energy spending for every family that receives the maximal benefit of these incentives.<ref>{{Cite web |last=House |first=The White |date=2022-08-15 |title=BY THE NUMBERS: The Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/08/15/by-the-numbers-the-inflation-reduction-act/ |access-date=2022-08-23 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref> The bill includes a 30% tax credit ($1,200 to $2,000 per year) and different types of rebates (reaching $14,000) for homeowners who will increase the energy efficiency of their house. In some cases, all upgrade expenses will be returned.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Iacurci |first1=Greg |title=Consumers may qualify for up to $10,000 — or more — in climate tax breaks and rebates in the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/08/13/how-to-qualify-for-inflation-reduction-act-climate-tax-breaks-rebates.html |access-date=8 September 2022 |agency=CNBC |date=13 August 2022}}</ref>

The bill allocates $3 billion for helping disadvantaged communities with [[Sustainable Transportation|transportation]] matters, including reconnecting communities separated by transport infrastructure, assuring safe and affordable transportation "and community engagement activities."<ref name=":04"/> This should improve [[transit-oriented development]].<ref>{{cite web |title=FACT SHEET: Inflation Reduction Act Advances Environmental Justice |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/08/17/fact-sheet-inflation-reduction-act-advances-environmental-justice/ |website=The White House |date=August 17, 2022 |access-date=14 September 2022}}</ref> Projects improving connectivity and [[walkability]] in these neighborhoods can get grants reaching 80%-100% of the overall cost.<ref>{{cite web |title=How States and Cities Can Benefit From Climate Investments in the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.americanprogress.org/article/how-states-and-cities-can-benefit-from-climate-investments-in-the-inflation-reduction-act/ |website=Center for American Progress |access-date=14 September 2022}}</ref> The bill also supports [[biking]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Banayan |first1=Noa |title=What IS in the Inflation Reduction Act for Bikes? |url=https://www.peopleforbikes.org/news/what-is-in-the-inflation-reduction-act-for-bikes |website=People for Bikes |access-date=14 September 2022}}</ref>

There are also funds allocated to national [[Sustainable energy|clean energy]] production. This includes the continuation of the production tax credit ($30 billion) and investment tax credit ($10 billion) toward clean energy manufacturing, including [[Solar power in the United States|solar power]], [[Wind power in the United States|wind power]], and [[grid energy storage]]. Some $14 billion of the clean energy package will go to rural areas, and include building [[biofuel]] infrastructure.<ref name=":04" /><ref name="Stabenow one-pager">[https://www.agriculture.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/ag_reconciliation_one-pager.pdf Senate Agriculture Committee one-pager, retrieved October 20, 2022]</ref>

The bill also provides funds toward the [[Low-carbon economy|decarbonization]] of the economy in other areas, providing various [[tax credit]]s and [[Grant (money)|grants]] and [[loan]]s toward decarbonizing the [[Industry in the United States|industrial]] and [[Transportation in the United States|transportation]] sectors. One $27 billion decarbonization grant and loan program is a [[green bank]] established by amending the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]], which is expected to generate high rates of return for the government from private sector investments.<ref name="Morgan Lewis 2022"/><ref name="Burr & Forman LLP 2022"/><ref name="Cherny 2022"/> The grant package also includes a program to reduce [[methane emissions]] from production and transportation of [[Natural gas in the United States|natural gas]]. The bill also provides for a focus on communities and [[environmental justice]] by providing several grants targeting historically marginalized and disadvantaged communities that have been disproportionally impacted by environmental pollution and climate change.<ref name=":04" />

The bill also allocates funds for rural communities, racial and economic justice in farming, [[marine ecosystem]]s and [[Forests of the United States|forestland]], including $20 billion to invest in [[climate-smart agriculture]], $5 billion to invest in [[forest conservation]] and [[urban tree]] planting, $3.1 billion to help farmers with high-risk operations caused by USDA-backed loans, $2.6 billion to protect and restore [[coastal habitats]], and $2.2 billion to redress proven claims from farmers of discrimination by the [[USDA]]'s lending programs.<ref name=":04" /><ref name="DOE/OP-0018"/><ref name="Stabenow one-pager"/><ref name="Philpott 2022"/>

The bill should cut the global greenhouse gas emissions by a level similar to "eliminating the annual planet-warming pollution of [[Climate change in France|France]] and [[Climate change in Germany|Germany]] combined" and may help to limit the warming of the planet to 1.5 degrees Celsius - the target of the [[Paris Agreement]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rathi |first1=Akshat |last2=A Dlouhy |first2=Jennifer |title=Bill Gates and the Secret Push to Save Biden's Climate Bill |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2022-08-16/how-bill-gates-lobbied-to-save-the-climate-tax-bill-biden-just-signed |access-date=19 September 2022 |agency=Bloomberg |date=August 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hirji |first1=Zahra |last2=Roston |first2=Eric |title=US Climate Bill Keeps Hope Alive for Halting Warming at 1.5°C |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-08-12/us-climate-bill-keeps-hope-alive-for-halting-warming-at-1-5-c#xj4y7vzkg |access-date=22 September 2022 |agency=Bloomberg |date=13 August 2022}}</ref> With the bill and additional federal and state measures, the USA can fulfill its pledge in the Paris Agreement: 50% greenhouse gas emissions reductions by the year 2030.<ref name=Rhodium/><ref>{{cite book |last1=MAHAJAN |first1=MEGAN |last2=ASHMOORE |first2=OLIVIA |last3=RISSMAN |first3=JEFFREY |last4=ORVIS |first4=ROBBIE |last5=GOPAL |first5=ANAND |title=MODELING THE INFLATION REDUCTION ACT USING THE ENERGY POLICY SIMULATOR |date=August 2022 |publisher=Energy innovation |page=1 |url=https://energyinnovation.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Modeling-the-Inflation-Reduction-Act-with-the-US-Energy-Policy-Simulator_August.pdf |access-date=22 September 2022}}</ref>

An assessment by the [[Rhodium Group]], an independent research firm, estimated it would reduce national greenhouse gas emissions 32–42% below 2005 levels by 2030, compared to 24–35% under current policy while reducing household energy costs and improving energy security.<ref name=Rhodium>{{Cite web |title=A Turning Point for US Climate Progress: Assessing the Climate and Clean Energy Provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://rhg.com/research/climate-clean-energy-inflation-reduction-act/ |access-date=2022-08-16 |website=Rhodium Group |language=en-US}}</ref> Furthermore, Rhodium Group projects that the nuclear provisions in the bill are likely to "keep much, if not all" of [[Nuclear power in the United States|the nation's nuclear reactors]] that are at risk of retiring, estimated to be 22–38% of the fleet, online through the 2030s.<ref>{{cite news |last=Natter |first=Ari |date= August 3, 2022|title=Manchin Deal Tosses $30 Billion Lifeline to US Nuclear Reactors |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-08-03/machin-deal-tosses-30-billion-lifeline-to-us-nuclear-reactors |url-status=live |access-date=2022-08-04 |work=Bloomberg}}</ref>

A preliminary analysis by the REPEAT Project of [[Princeton University]] estimated that the investments made by the law would reduce net emissions 42% below 2005 levels, compared to 27% under current policies (including the [[Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act]]).<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ebbs |first=Stephanie |title=Experts explain how the Inflation Reduction Act helps fight climate change |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/experts-explain-inflation-reduction-act-helps-fight-climate/story?id=88100442 |access-date=2022-08-18 |website=ABC News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=princeton.edu |date=August 4, 2022 |title=Preliminary Report: The Climate and Energy Impacts of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://repeatproject.org/docs/REPEAT_IRA_Prelminary_Report_2022-08-12.pdf |access-date=2022-08-18 |website=repeatproject.org}}</ref>

The Energy Innovation group estimated the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions at 37–41% below 2005 levels in 2030, compared to 24% without the bill.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web |title=Modeling The Inflation Reduction Act Using The Energy Policy Simulator |url=https://energyinnovation.org/publication/modeling-the-inflation-reduction-act-using-the-energy-policy-simulator/ |access-date=2022-08-01 |publisher=Energy Innovation}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Storrow |first=Benjamin |title=How Much Will the Climate Bill Reduce Emissions? It Depends |url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-much-will-the-climate-bill-reduce-emissions-it-depends/ |access-date=2022-08-18 |website=Scientific American |language=en}}</ref> This estimate of the greenhouse gas emission reduction lines up with the figure provided by the bill's authors which is a 40% reduction in carbon emissions relative to 2005 levels.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Newburger |first=Emma |title=Schumer-Manchin reconciliation bill has $369 billion to fight climate change — here are the details |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/07/27/schumer-manchin-reconciliation-bill-climate-change-provisions.html |access-date=2022-08-01 |website=CNBC}}</ref>

Modeling from the nonpartisan research institution [[Resources for the Future]] indicates the bill would decrease retail power costs by 5.2–6.7% over a ten-year period, resulting in savings of $170–220 per year for the average U.S. household. The modeling also predicts that the bill would tend to stabilize electricity prices.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Retail Electricity Rates under the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.rff.org/publications/issue-briefs/retail-electricity-rates-under-the-inflation-reduction-act-of-2022/ |access-date=2022-08-06 |publisher=Resources for the Future}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Axios Generate, August 5, 2022 |url=https://www.axios.com/newsletters/axios-generate-90a5dde8-7916-4c69-967c-fe1f9d1665f8.html |access-date=2022-08-05 |website=Axios}}</ref> The bill would help foster a tripling in the size of the American solar power industry and provide unprecedented investment security, according to the trade group [[Solar Energy Industries Association]].<ref name="Stevens 2022">{{cite web | last=Stevens | first=Pippa | title=Solar installations will triple by 2027 thanks to climate bill, report predicts | website=CNBC | date=8 September 2022 | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/09/08/solar-installations-will-nearly-triple-over-the-next-five-years-seia.html | access-date=29 October 2022}}</ref>

In reaction to the Supreme Court case ''[[West Virginia v. EPA]]'', which limited the EPA's authority to institute a program such as the Obama-era [[Clean Power Plan]], the IRA also includes language granting the EPA more authority to regulate carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, as well as to promote renewable energy.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/22/climate/epa-supreme-court-pollution.html | title=Democrats Designed the Climate Law to be a Game Changer. Here's How | newspaper=The New York Times | date=August 22, 2022 | last1=Friedman | first1=Lisa }}</ref>

=== Taxes and distributional impact ===
[[File:20220826 Share of unpaid taxes, by income level - area chart, treemap - NYTimes - Dept of Treasury.svg|thumb|U.S. Treasury Department estimates of unpaid taxes indicate that over half of all unpaid taxes are attributable to the top 5% of earners.<ref name=NYTimes_20220826>{{cite news |last1=Lopez |first1=German |last2=Wu |first2=Ashley |title=Conspiracy Theories / How more funding for the I.R.S. became a political firestorm |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/26/briefing/conspiracy-irs-tax-agency-fraud.html |work=The New York Times |date=August 26, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220826102900/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/26/briefing/conspiracy-irs-tax-agency-fraud.html |archive-date=August 26, 2022 |quote=Source: U.S. Department of Treasury; Estimates from 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref>]]
Excerpts from the nonpartisan [[Joint Committee on Taxation]] (JCT) indicated that the legislation might lead to increased payments on personal taxes for Americans of all incomes (an increase in $16.7{{nbsp}}billion for taxpayers earning less than $200,000 a year, $14.1{{nbsp}}billion for taxpayers earning between $200,000 and $500,000, and $23.5{{nbsp}}billion for taxpayers earning over $500,000). This calculation was based on the assumption that companies would indirectly pass on parts of the minimum corporate tax to employees, an assumption that was criticized by Steven M. Rosenthal, a senior fellow at the nonpartisan [[Tax Policy Center]] (TPC).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Diaz |first1=Daniella|last2=Luhby|first2=Tami  |title=Republicans argue Manchin and Schumer's energy, health care deal will raise taxes, citing nonpartisan data |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/31/politics/republicans-economic-bill-taxes-inflation/index.html |access-date=2022-07-31 |work=CNN|date=July 31, 2022 }}</ref> Economist [[William G. Gale]], who is also co-director of the TPC, comments that it is important to consider that the calculations by the JCT did not take into account the provisions in the bill that would extend premium tax credits for health plans for low- and middle-income taxpayers, provide households with tax credits for making their property more energy-efficient, and lower the price of prescription drugs.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-02 |title=Putting JCT's Score of the Inflation Reduction Act Into Context |url=https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/putting-jcts-score-inflation-reduction-act-context |access-date=2022-08-03 |publisher=Tax Policy Center}}</ref>

The [[Tax Policy Center]] estimated that the bottom 80% tax filers by income would receive a net benefit, if ACA premium tax credits (subsidies) are included. The 80th-99th percentile would incur a small cost (0-0.1% increase in average federal tax rate) while the top 1% would incur a 0.2% increase. The costs mainly are imposed indirectly as corporations facing higher taxes may reduce the wage increases or levels for workers; individual tax rates were not changed.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The Inflation Reduction Act Primarily Impacts Top 1 Percent of Taxpayers|language=en-US|work=taxpolicycenter.org|url=https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/inflation-reduction-act-primarily-impacts-top-1-percent-taxpayers|date=2022-08-11}}</ref>

Treasury Secretary [[Janet Yellen]] directed [[IRS Commissioner]] [[Charles Rettig]] to not use the new funding allocated in the bill to increase the rate of audits of those making less than $400,000 a year above historical levels, but to instead focus on "high-end noncompliance."<ref>{{Cite web |author=Kate Sullivan |title=Yellen directs IRS not to use new funding to increase chances of audits of Americans making less than $400,000 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/10/politics/yellen-new-irs-funding-audits/index.html |access-date=2022-08-11 |website=CNN|date=August 11, 2022 }}</ref>

The Treasury and [[Internal Revenue Service]] published guidance on eligibility for electric vehicle owners to claim tax credits worth between $3,500 - $7,500, including outlining a requirement for the vehicle to have a final assembly in North America. The [[Department of Energy (United States)|Department of Energy]] and the [[Department of Transportation (U.S.)|Department of Transportation]] also published resources identifying vehicles that will likely meet all requirements for tax credit.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Davis |first=Jeffrey |title=Treasury Releases Initial Information On Electric Vehicle Tax Credit Under Newly Enacted Inflation Reduction Act - Tax Authorities - United States |url=https://www.mondaq.com/unitedstates/tax-authorities/1223028/treasury-releases-initial-information-on-electric-vehicle-tax-credit-under-newly-enacted-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=Mayer Brown}}</ref><ref name=":03">{{Cite web |title=The $369bn Climate Deal: America's Path To Climate Resilience - Renewables - United States |url=https://www.mofo.com/resources/insights/220810-369bn-climate-deal-americas-path-to-climate-resilience |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=Morrison Foerster}}</ref> The [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] indicated that their list of eligible vehicles is not a guarantee for credit, and states that the [[Vehicle identification number|Vehicle Identification Number]] (VIN) will give full manufacturing details and locations.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Alternative Fuels Data Center: Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://afdc.energy.gov/laws/inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=US Department of Energy |language=en}}</ref> Those qualified will receive the tax credits, known as the Clean Vehicle Credit, previously called the Qualified Plug-In Electric Drive Motor Vehicle Credit. The [[United States Department of the Treasury|US Treasury Department]] has also stated that owners who purchase eligible vehicles previous to August 16, 2022 but did not possess the vehicle until after that date, also qualify for the Clean Vehicle Credit.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lucero |first=Kat |title=Feds Spell Out EV Tax Breaks Under Inflation Reduction Act - Law360 |url=https://www.law360.com/tax-authority/articles/1521750/feds-spell-out-ev-tax-breaks-under-inflation-reduction-act |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=Law 360 |language=en}}</ref> However, because of the requirement that qualified EVs must have "at least 40 percent of materials sourced from North America or a US trading partner by 2024" and the batteries cannot contain minerals that "were extracted, processed, or recycled by a foreign entity of concern", most currently available EVs on the market will not qualify for the tax credits.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hawkins |first=Andrew J. |date=2022-08-08 |title=No electric vehicles on the market today qualify for the new EV tax credit |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/8/8/23296678/ev-tax-credit-qualify-battery-supply-chain-china |access-date=2022-08-29 |website=The Verge |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Kaplan |first=Tim Levin, Juliana |title=Most electric cars won't qualify for Democrats' new $7,500 tax credit |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-ev-tax-credit-inflation-reduction-build-back-better-tesla-2022-8 |access-date=2022-08-29 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}}</ref>

Additional tax credits were presented in the bill for energy efficiency in buildings, expanding current incentives in a tier-based system beginning in 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=August 19 |first1=Jack Rogers {{!}} |last2=AM |first2=2022 at 08:08 |title=Inflation Reduction Act Doubles Tax Credits for Building Retrofits |url=https://www.globest.com/2022/08/19/inflation-reduction-act-doubles-tax-credits-for-building-retrofits/ |access-date=2022-08-21 |website=GlobeSt |language=en}}</ref> The bill specifies that commercial buildings must update efficiency by 25%, compared to a reference building, to qualify for $0.50 per square foot of tax credit for the first tier, increasing to a maximum of $5.00 per square foot for the final tier. The tax credits also extends to single and multi-family housing, requiring 50% less annual energy consumption compared to similar units.<ref name=":03" />  Vincent Barnes, a senior vice president from Alliance to Save Energy in Washington, D.C, stated that these policies were meant to reduce energy costs and demand on the power grid.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ebeling |first=Ashlea |date=2022-08-08 |title=Inflation Reduction Act Is Big Win for Serial Green-Home Remodelers |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/climate-and-tax-bill-is-big-win-for-serial-green-home-remodelers-11659971356 |access-date=2022-08-21 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

== Reactions ==
Senator [[Joe Manchin]] (D-WV) issued a statement for his support of the bill.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |last2=Luhby |first2=Tami |title=Manchin and Schumer announce deal for energy and health care bill |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/07/27/politics/schumer-manchin-deal-build-back-better/index.html |access-date=July 27, 2022 |work=CNN}}</ref> President [[Joe Biden]] also stated his support for the proposed bill.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=July 27, 2022 |title=Statement from President Biden on Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/07/27/statement-from-president-biden-on-inflation-reduction-act-of-2022/ |access-date=July 27, 2022 |website=The White House}}</ref> On August 4, Senator [[Kyrsten Sinema]] (D-AZ) issued a statement indicating that she would support the bill after striking a deal with fellow Democrats to change several tax provisions.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Democrats, Sinema reach deal on new taxes in Inflation Reduction Act |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2022/08/04/inflation-reduction-act-sinema/ |access-date=2022-08-05 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

Congressional Republicans have voiced unanimous opposition to the bill, claiming the legislation would do little to combat inflation, or would exacerbate it. Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] (R-KY) denounced the legislation as "reckless spending" and Ranking Member of the Senate Budget Committee [[Lindsey Graham]] (R-SC) called it "insanity".

In a letter sent to congressional leadership and touted by Senate Democrats, 126 economists including [[Robert Rubin]], [[Jack Lew]], [[Jason Furman]], [[Lawrence Summers]], [[Mark Zandi]], and [[Joseph Stiglitz]], wrote that the bill is more than fully paid for, lowers prices for consumers and will lower inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Betsy Klein |title=First on CNN: Top economists say Democrats' health care and climate package will put 'downward pressure on inflation' |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/02/politics/economists-democrats-package-downward-pressure-inflation/index.html |access-date=2022-08-14 |website=CNN|date=August 2, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=August 1, 2022 |title=The Inflation Reduction Act Will Reduce Inflation |url=https://www.democrats.senate.gov/dpcc/press-releases/the-inflation-reduction-act-will-reduce-inflation |access-date=2022-08-05 |publisher=Senate Democratic Leadership}}</ref>

In a letter sent to House and Senate leadership, 230 economists wrote that "the legislation will actually contribute to inflation" and "will add to price rises." The economists include "Nobel laureate [[Vernon L. Smith|Vernon Smith]], former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers [[Kevin Hassett]], former director of the Office of Management and Budget [[James C. Miller III|Jim Miller]], and [[H. Robert Heller|Robert Heller]], president of the Federal Reserve Board from 1986 to 1989. In addition, professors from the University of Chicago, Princeton University, Duke University, the University of Virginia, Columbia University and the University of Notre Dame signed the letter."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Financial Review |first=Matthew Cranston |title=Why inflation is a hot-button political issue in the US |url=https://www.afr.com/world/north-america/americans-are-likely-to-have-long-memories-on-inflation-20220809-p5b8kt |access-date=2022-09-26 |website=Financial Review|date=August 12, 2022 }}</ref>

Tom Philpott, an agriculture journalist writing in [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'']], praised the bill's investments in climate-smart agriculture and remedies for USDA loan discrimination, but heavily criticized Sinema's deletion of the carried interest loophole modification and the lack of provisions to expand funding for the [[National School Lunch Act]] and improvements to child nutrition (as expressed in the original [[Build Back Better Act]]) and for [[soil erosion]] prevention programs (which enhance small-scale [[carbon farming]] and encourage a shift away from [[monoculture]]-dependent farming for [[ethanol fuel in the United States]]).<ref name="Philpott 2022"/>

=== Public organizations ===
[[Darren Woods]], the CEO of oil and gas energy giant [[ExxonMobil]], called the bill "a step in the right direction" and endorsed its provisions related to oil and gas.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Crowley |first1=Kevin |date=July 30, 2022 |title=Exxon CEO Loves What Manchin Did for Big Oil in $370 Billion Deal |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-07-29/exxon-s-woods-calls-manchin-bill-step-in-the-right-direction |access-date=July 30, 2022 |website=Bloomberg}}</ref> Multiple coal industry groups, including the West Virginia Coal Association, criticized the bill for "[obviating] any need to innovate coal assets" and doing "nothing for coal or coal generation".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Alexander |first1=Bolton |title=Coal industry 'shocked and disheartened' by Manchin climate deal |url=https://www.wfxrtv.com/news/regional-news/west-virginia-news/coal-industry-shocked-and-disheartened-by-manchin-climate-deal/ |website=WFXRtv |publisher=The Hill |date=August 4, 2022|access-date=August 9, 2022}}</ref>

Many mainstream environmental organizations supported the bill, such as the [[The Nature Conservancy|Nature Conservancy]], the [[National Wildlife Federation]], and [[American Forests]].<ref name=":6">{{Cite news |last=Dennis |first=Brady |date=14 August 2022 |title=As Congress funds high-tech climate solutions, it also bets on a low-tech one: Nature |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/08/14/nature-climate-solutions-inflation-reduction-act/ |access-date=16 August 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=A "New Day for Climate Action in the United States" as U.S. Congress Passes Historic Clean Energy and Climate Investments |url=https://www.nature.org/en-us/newsroom/us-house-passes-landmark-climate-bill/ |access-date=2022-08-17 |website=The Nature Conservancy |language=en-US}}</ref> The director of North America policy for the Nature Conservancy, Tom Cors, called the legislation "historic", while Aviva Glaser of the NWF called the infusion of spending "transformative." The [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] argued that despite continued acceptance of fossil fuels in the IRA, its climate mitigation policies would outweigh their impact ten times over.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Plumer |first1=Brad |last2=Friedman |first2=Lisa |date=2022-07-30 |title=Democrats Got a Climate Bill. Joe Manchin Got Drilling, and More. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/30/climate/manchin-climate-deal.html |access-date=2022-08-17 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Health and environmental justice organizations like [[Earthjustice]] have welcomed the law.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Jaffe |first=Susan |date=2022-09-03 |title=Health organisations welcome US climate crisis law |url=https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(22)01663-4/abstract |journal=The Lancet |language=English |volume=400 |issue=10354 |pages=719–720 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(22)01663-4 |issn=0140-6736 |pmid=36058212|s2cid=251984511 }}</ref>

However, not all environmental groups expressed unqualified support. Some environmentalists noted that the bill contained more "[[Carrot and stick|carrots]]", or incentives for positive behavior, than "[[Carrot and stick|sticks]]", or new regulations.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Leber |first=Rebecca |date=2022-08-16 |title=4 underrated parts of the Inflation Reduction Act |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2022/8/16/23306588/biden-inflation-reduction-act-climate-pollution-energy |access-date=2022-08-17 |website=Vox |language=en}}</ref> Several groups argued that as the legislation did not seek to eliminate fossil fuels entirely, it was inadequate to meet the threat of climate change. Jean Su, the energy justice program director at the [[Center for Biological Diversity]], called the legislation "a backdoor take-it-or-leave-it deal between a coal baron and Democratic leaders in which any opposition from lawmakers or frontline communities was quashed."<ref name="More harm than good">{{cite web |last1=Lakhani |first1=Nina |date=August 9, 2022 |title=Landmark US climate bill will do more harm than good, groups say |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/aug/09/us-climate-bill-fossil-fuel-harm-environment-biden |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220812091207/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/aug/09/us-climate-bill-fossil-fuel-harm-environment-biden |archive-date=August 12, 2022 |access-date=August 12, 2022 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> The [[Climate Justice Alliance]] criticized the IRA, saying that "the strengths of the IRA are outweighed by the bill's weaknesses and threats posed by the expansion of fossil fuels and unproven technologies such as carbon capture and hydrogen generation."<ref name="More harm than good" />

The heads of the [[National Cooperative Business Association]], [[National Rural Electric Cooperative Association]], [[National Farmers Union (United States)|National Farmers Union]], and National Council of Farming Cooperatives praised the IRA for its provisions assisting cooperatives in energy and agriculture, particularly direct grants and debt forgiveness. Cornelius Blanding, head of the U.S. Federation of Southern Cooperatives, also praised the IRA, but expressed concern that its revisions of the American Rescue Plan's debt relief programs for minority farmers would worsen racial discrimination in agriculture.<ref name="Lechleitner 2022"/>

Cycling organizations criticized the IRA for removing the incentives for [[electric bicycle]]s in the original Build Back Better Act, having a better energy-per-incentive ratio and reaching a wider demographic, than for [[electric car]]s remaining in the IRA.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Toll |first1=Micah |date=8 August 2022 |title=The new climate bill abandoned the type of electric vehicle that can make the biggest difference |url=https://electrek.co/2022/08/07/the-new-climate-bill-abandoned-the-type-of-electric-vehicle-that-can-make-the-biggest-difference/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220808181648/https://electrek.co/2022/08/07/the-new-climate-bill-abandoned-the-type-of-electric-vehicle-that-can-make-the-biggest-difference/ |archive-date=8 August 2022 |website=[[Electrek]]}}</ref> Sean Jeans-Gail, Vice President of Government Affairs and Policy at the [[Rail Passengers Association]], criticized the IRA saying,"It's a bitter pill in terms of rail and transit, which is the one clearly established, low-carbon emission transportation systems we have going". He also criticized the bill for being car centric.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Weinberg |first1=Harrison |title='It's so blatant': Transit groups bemoan Dems' car-centric climate deal |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/07/28/transit-democrats-car-climate-deal-00048599 |access-date=August 26, 2022 |website=Politico |publisher=Alex Daugherty}}</ref>

Twenty-seven [[European Union]] finance ministers have expressed they had "serious concerns" about the financial incentives of the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act, and are considering to challenge it. They have listed at least nine points in the legislation, which they say could be in breach of [[World Trade Organization|World Trade Organisation]] rules. One of their major points was being opposed to the subsidies for consumers to buy North American assembled [[electric car]]s as EU officials believe it is discriminating against European carmakers. One EU official told [[CNBC]] that, “there is a political consensus (among the 27 ministers) that this plan threatens the European industry.” Representatives from [[South Korea]] have also voiced similar concerns to Europe, given that the legislation can also restrict [[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai's]] and other South Korean carmakers' business in the American market.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Best |first=Paul |date=2022-09-01 |title=EU hits US for Inflation Reduction Act electric vehicle tax credit requiring final assembly in North America |url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/eu-hits-us-electric-vehicle-tax-credit-requires-final-assembly-cars-north-america |access-date=2022-09-03 |website=FOXBusiness |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Palmer |first=Doug |title=USTR shrugs off EU criticism of EV tax credit |url=https://politi.co/3C8qKYS |access-date=2022-09-03 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Amaro |first=Silvia |title=Europe shows a united front against Biden's Inflation Reduction Act, says it threatens industry |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/11/09/europe-shows-a-united-front-against-bidens-inflation-reduction-act.html |access-date=2022-12-25 |website=CNBC |language=en}}</ref>

Some members of the trade union [[United Auto Workers]], including the vice president Cindy Estrada, have obliquely commented to ''[[The American Prospect]]'' that the Inflation Reduction Act's implementation regarding [[prevailing wage]] requirements and [[collective bargaining]] rights (particularly at startup EV factories) may be weakened, and that if not properly implemented, the Act could be linked to poor hiring practices and working conditions.<ref name="Harris 2022">{{cite web | last=Harris | first=Lee | title=Industrial Policy Without Industrial Unions | website=The American Prospect | date=28 September 2022 | url=https://prospect.org/api/content/aff4b44e-3e71-11ed-9b46-12274efc5439/ | access-date=5 October 2022}}</ref>
